newsitem.title: CANADA: Quebec battles with municipalities on deficit plan.
newsitem.headline: Quebec battles with municipalities on deficit plan.

text.p: The Quebec government is battling the French-speaking province's debt-burdened municipalities over its tough budget austerity plan.

As part of its bid to clean up its finances ahead of a provincial election by 1999 and a third possible referendum on independence, the separatist Quebec government wants the province's more than 1,500 municipalities to absorb C$500 million of annual expenses.
The move is part of the Parti Quebecois government's effort to meet its deficit target of C$2.2 billion for fiscal 1997/98 ending March 31.
The municipalities, their tax bases hurt by a sluggish economy and moribund property values, are protesting the move, saying they will have to raise taxes or cut services.

On Wednesday, the Quebec Union of Municipalities countered Quebec's plan with its own proposals showing how the government could trim C$412 million from its expenditures without asking cities, towns and villages to tighten the belt.

"If the government is serious about cleaning up its public finances without crushing the citizens with taxes, it will consent to rapidly implement our measures," said Quebec Union of Municipalities President Mario Laframboise.
Quebec Treasury Board President Jacques Leonard rejected the idea, saying the municipalities should look at the C$222 million of surpluses sitting in their employees' pension funds.
Analysts said Quebec municipalities were already heavily indebted and their tax rates among the highest in Canada.
"In general, Quebec cities have fairly low credit ratings because their debt levels are high," said Doug Hirano, senior financial analyst at Dominion Bond Rating Service.
The provincial debt in Quebec, which has a population of 7.1 million, is about C$77 billion, while its municipalities, school boards and hospitals carry a debt load of C$26 billion.
By contrast, Ontario, with a population of 10 million, has a provincial debt of C$102 billion, with its municipalities, schools and hospitals responsible for only C$6 billion of debt.
"The Quebec municipalities are much weaker fiscally than those in Ontario. They are just trying to protect their turf," said Hirano.
